{{No footnotes|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox royalty | reign = 3 January 1701 –
20 February 1731 | predecessor = [[Louis I, Prince of Monaco|Louis I]] | successor = [[Louise Hippolyte, Princess of Monaco|Louise Hippolyte]] | name = Antonio I | succession = [[Prince of Monaco]] | image = 1706 - Antoine I Grimaldi (Monaco).jpg | house = [[House of Grimaldi|Grimaldi]] | full name = Antonio Grimaldi | father = [[Louis I, Prince of Monaco]] | mother = [[Catherine Charlotte de Gramont]] | spouse = [[Marie of Lorraine]] | issue = [[Louise Hippolyte, Princess of Monaco]]
Margherita Camilla, Princess of Isenghien | birth_date = {{birth date|1661|1|25|df=y}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1731|2|20|1661|1|25|df=y}} }} '''Antonio I''' (25 January 1661 – 20 February 1731) was the sovereign [[Prince of Monaco]] from 1701 to 1731. He was the elder son of [[Louis I, Prince of Monaco|Louis I of Monaco]] and [[Catherine Charlotte de Gramont]]. In 1683 Antonio was named lieutenant in the [[Régiment du Roi|Régiment du Roi Infanterie]]. In 1684 he was named colonel of the regiment of Soissonois. During the [[Nine Years War]] he was present at the Battle of [[Philippsburg]] (1688), the [[Battle of Fleurus (1690)|Battle of Fleurus]] (1690), the [[Siege of Mons (1691)|Siege of Mons]] (1691), and the [[Siege of Namur (1692)|Siege of Namur]] (1692). On 21 August 1702 Antonio took the oath to King [[Louis XIV of France]] in the [[Parlement]] on account of being [[Duke of Valentinois]] and a [[Peer of France]]. He was made a knight of the French royal orders in 1724. ==Marriage and children== Antonio married 13 June 1688 [[Marie of Lorraine|Marie de Lorraine, "''Mademoiselle d'Armagnac''"]] (12 August 1674 – 30 October 1724), daughter of [[Louis, Count of Armagnac|Louis of Lorraine, Count Armagnac]]. They had six daughters of whom only three survived infancy : *Caterina Charlotte (7 October 1691 – 18 June 1696), "Mademoiselle de Monaco". *[[Louise Hippolyte, Princess of Monaco|Louise Hippolyte]] (10 November 1697 – 29 December 1731), successor of her father. *Elisabetta Charlotte (3 November 1698 – 25 August 1702), ''Mademoiselle de Valentinois''. *Margherita Camilla (1 May 1700 – 27 April 1758), "Mademoiselle de Carlades"; married on 16 April 1720 to Louis de Gand-Vilain, Prince of Isenghien and Marshal of France. *Maria Devota (15 March 1702 – 24 October 1703), "Mademoiselle des Baux". *Maria Paolina Theresa Devota (23 October 1708 – 20 May 1726), "Mademoiselle de Chabreuil". Antonio also had a number of illegitimate children: *with Elisabeth Durfort (a dancer) **[[Chevalier de Grimaldi|Antoine Grimaldi]] (1697–1784), known as ''Le Chevalier de Grimaldi'' *with Victoire Vertu (dancer at the Paris opera) **Antoinette Grimaldi, called ''mademoiselle de Saint-Rémy'' *with an unknown woman **Louise Marie Thérèse Grimaldi (1705–1723) ==Ancestors== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Antonio I, Prince of Monaco''' |2= 2. [[Louis I, Prince of Monaco]] |3= 3. [[Catherine Charlotte de Gramont]] |4= 4. [[Ercole of Monaco]] |5= 5. Maria Aurelia Spinola |6= 6. {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Arabs in Malta
Għarab f'Malta | population = 5,000+ | langs = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[Maltese language|Maltese]] | religions = Predominantly [[Islam]] | related = [[Arab people]], [[Arab diaspora]], [[Arab Americans]], [[Arab Argentine]], [[Arab Brazilian]], [[Arab Canadians]], [[Arab Mexican]] }} '''Arabs in Malta''' ([[Maltese language|Maltese]]: ''Għarab f'Malta'') are mostly [[Expatriate|expatriates]] from a range of [[Arab countries]], particularly [[Libya]] and [[Syria]]. This list includes both first-generation and second-generation expatriates. == Notable people == {{Expand list|date=June 2018}} * [[Rachid Chouhal]] (born 1975), athlete – born in [[Morocco]] * [[Carlo Gimach]] (1651–1730), architect, engineer and poet – descendant of a [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] refugee == See also == * [[Arab diaspora]] * [[Arabs in Europe]] * [[Syrian diaspora]] *[[Demographics of Malta]] *[[Immigration to Malta]] == References == {{Malta-stub}} [[Category:Arab diaspora in Europe]] [[Category:Demographics of Malta]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Malta]]

''' Australian Antarctic Building System ''' or '''AANBUS''' is a [[modular building|modular construction system]] used by the [[Australian Antarctic Division|Australian Government Antarctica Division]] for buildings in [[Antarctica]]. The individual modules resemble [[Intermodal container|shipping container]]s. Each module is approximately 3.6 metres by 6 metres by 4 metres high.
Buildings built using the AANBUS modules are placed on [[concrete]] [[Foundation (engineering)#Shallow foundations|footings]] anchored into the ground and do not need external [[guy wires]] to anchor and support them. The modules are built of [[steel]] with attached [[Building insulation|insulation]] and [[vapor barrier]]s.
The modular design provides improved shipping, speed of assembly in the short [[Antarctic]] summer and better testing before shipping. The ability to test the assembled modules allows corrections to be made in the convenience of construction sites in [[temperate climates]] with easy access to parts and equipment, rather than at remote Antarctic locations where shipping in of replacement parts is an arduous undertaking.
==Further reading== *{{Citation|title=AANBUS : the creation of a building system for Antarctica|last1=Incoll|first1=Philip|year=1980|publisher=Commonwealth of Australia Dept. of Housing & Construction|location=Canberra}}
== External links == *[http://www.antarctica.gov.au/about-antarctica/history/stations/history-of-australias-antarctic-buildings/aanbus-modular History of AANBUS] *[http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/station-life-and-activities/buildings-and-structures/aanbus-buildings Characteristics of the Australian Antarctic Building System]
[[Category:Buildings and structures in Antarctica]] [[Category:Australian architecture]] [[Category:Australian Antarctic Territory]]

{{Infobox radio station | name = Autoradio
({{lang-be|Аўтарадыё}}) | image = | city = [[Minsk]], [[Belarus]] | area = | branding = | slogan = "For those who are on the way." | frequency = {{Frequency|105.1|[[Minsk]] FM}} | translator = | repeater = | airdate = {{Start date|1992|8|7}} | last airdate = January 12, 2011 | share = | share as of = | share source = | format = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Popular music|Popular]] | language = [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]], [[Russian language|Russian]] | power = | erp = | haat = | class = | facility_id = | coordinates = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | former_frequencies = | affiliations = | owner = Joint Stock Company "Autoradio" | licensee = | sister_stations = | webcast = | website = }} '''Autoradio''' (105.1 Minsk FM) was the first independent [[radio station]] in the independent [[Belarus]]. Autoradio was the first radio station in Belarus to broadcast after the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union]]. It was broadcast from [[Minsk]] on the frequency 105.1 MHz from 7 August, 1992 to 12 January, 2011. ==History== From the early 90s until January 1, 1995, Autoradio operated on the frequency 67.7 [[FM broadcast band#OIRT bandplan|OIRT FM]]. At 12:40 p.m. on 12 January 2011, Autoradio's transmitting license was revoked at the station was shut down.[http://nn.by/?c=ar&i=48860 Закрытая «Аўтарадыё»] // [[Nasha Niva]] {{Ref-be}} The Republican Commission on Television and Radio decided to annul the rights of Autoradio due to Autoradio's broadcasting of opponents of [[Alexander Lukashenko|Lukashenka's regime]] during the [[Belarusian presidential election, 2010|2010 Belarusian presidential election]]. == See also == * [[Radio 101.2 (Belarus)]] * [[105.1 FM]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Belarus}} [[Category:Radio stations in Belarus]] [[Category:1992 establishments in Belarus]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1992]] {{Europe-radio-station-stub}}

Alex Tien
Danny Huang | hongkongfilmwards = | goldenbauhiniaawards = | hkfcsawards = | asianfilmawards = | goldenhorseawards = | huabiaoawards = | goldenroosterawards = | hundredflowersawards = | goldeneagleawards = | flyingapsarasawards = | rthktop10goldsongsawards= | goldenmelodyawards = '''Best Group'''
2003 ''All I...'' | mtvasiaawards = | ntsawards = | chinamusicawards = | goldenbellawards = | tvbanniversaryawards = | magnoliaawards = | asiantvawards = | rainbowawards = | awards = }} '''B. A. D.''' was a former [[Taiwan]]ese [[boy band]] whose members are Ben Pai, Alex Tien, and Danny Huang. The group's name derives from the initials of the members' given name. Pai, Tien, and Huang met at a singing competition in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], and began working together in the spring of 1998.{{cite web |url=http://music.ent.tom.com/Archive/1073/1283/2003/2/17-10405.html|title=B.A.D乐队组合介绍及大事记|accessdate=2008-07-30|date=2003-02-17|publisher=[[TOM Online]]|language=Chinese}} The trio was recommended to Liu Wei-tz'u, a manager who eventually sent them to Taiwan to work with [[EMI]]. Under EMI, the trio released their debut studio album, ''Not Quiet'', on 30 December 2000. Although B.A.D's début went under the radar, their second album, released in November 2001,{{cite web|url=http://isrc.ncl.edu.tw/query/uaudiodata.asp?audiocode=0000002882 |script-title=zh:專輯詳細資料 |accessdate=2008-07-30 |publisher=[[International Standard Recording Code]] |language=Chinese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041216114407/http://isrc.ncl.edu.tw/query/uaudiodata.asp?audiocode=0000002882 |archivedate=December 16, 2004 }} put the group into the spotlight. That album, ''All I...'', earned a Best Group Award at the 13th [[Golden Melody Awards]] and a nomination for Best New Artist at the 8th CMA Awards.{{cite web |url=http://ent.sina.com.cn/p/i/2002-01-23/70832.html|script-title=zh:华语音乐榜中榜--短信投票最受欢迎新人奖候选名单|accessdate=2008-07-30|date=2002-01-23|publisher=Sina.com|language=Chinese}}{{cite web|url=http://info.gio.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=13498&ctNode=1220&mp=1 |script-title=zh:第十三屆金曲獎得獎名單 |accessdate=2008-07-30 |date=2004-04-28 |publisher=[[Government Information Office]] |language=Chinese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316144018/http://info.gio.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=13498&ctNode=1220&mp=1 |archivedate=2008-03-16 }} In 2003, B.A.D. was nominated again for Best Group at the Golden Melody Awards,{{cite web|url=http://info.gio.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=13534&ctNode=1220&mp=1 |script-title=zh:第十四屆金曲獎入圍名單 |accessdate=2008-07-30 |date=2004-04-29 |publisher=Government Information Office |language=Chinese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427155359/http://info.gio.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=13534&ctNode=1220&mp=1 |archivedate=2009-04-27 |df= }} but lost to [[S.H.E]].{{cite web|url=http://info.gio.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=13461&ctNode=1220&mp=1 |script-title=zh:第十四屆金曲獎得獎名單 |accessdate=2008-07-30 |date=2004-04-29 |publisher=Government Information Office |language=Chinese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427155323/http://info.gio.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=13461&ctNode=1220&mp=1 |archivedate=2009-04-27 }} ==Members== The members of B.A.D. grew up in Taiwan prior to studying in the United States. Ben Pai, born 2 August 1979, attended [[California State University, Los Angeles]] during his tenure with the group.{{cite web |url=http://music.ent.tom.com/Archive/1073/1283/2003/2/17-40977.html|title=B.A.D完全档案|accessdate=2008-07-30|date=2003-02-17|publisher=|language=Chinese}} Alex Tien, born 12 September 1979, attended the [[University of Southern California]] during his time with the group, and graduated in June 2002. Danny Huang, born 9 July 1978, was a student at the [[Musicians Institute]]. For most B.A.D. tracks, Pai sings the high notes, Tien sings the middle notes, and Huang sings the low notes. ==Discography== * ''Not Quiet'' (2000) * ''All I...'' (2001) * ''Song To My Lovely Queen'' (2002) * ''Beginning of My Dream'' (2003) * ''B.A.D'' (2004) ==Awards and nominations== At the 3rd Global Chinese Music Awards, two songs—"Half an Ocean" and "Kingston's Dream"—combined to form B.A.D.'s nomination for Best Group. Best Group honours were ultimately won by Yu Quan, who won the Bronze Award, [[Twins (group)|Twins]] and S.H.E, who shared the Silver, and [[F4 (band)|F4]], who won the Gold Award.{{cite web|url=http://music.ent.tom.com/1026/1369/2003919-24170.html|script-title=zh:第三届全球华语歌曲排行榜之完全获奖名单|accessdate=2008-07-18|publisher=TOM Online|date=2003-09-19|language=Chinese|title=Archived copy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060626105528/http://music.ent.tom.com/1026/1369/2003919-24170.html|archive-date=2006-06-26|dead-url=yes|df=}} {| class="wikitable sortable" !Year !Award The '''Beltsville Information Management Center''' ('''BIMC'''), formerly named the '''Beltsville Messaging Center''' ('''BMC''') and the '''Beltsville Communications Center''' (also known as the '''Beltsville Communications Annex'''), is a [[United States Department of State]] facility located in [[Beltsville, Maryland|Beltsville]], [[Maryland]], next door to the U.S. [[Special Collection Service]] (SCS).<ref name=pike96>{{cite web |last=Pike |first=John |title=State Department: Beltsville Communications Annex |date=April 28, 1996 |publisher=[[Federation of American Scientists]] |url=http://www.fas.org/irp/facility/odell.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010803054524/http://www.fas.org/irp/facility/odell.htm |archivedate=August 3, 2001 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> It serves as the primary relay facility for the [[Diplomatic Telecommunications Service]] and services the communications needs of various U.S. government programs and agencies, including the SCS.
==History== Prior to 1985, the Department of State's telecommunications system resided at the [[Harry S Truman Building|department's headquarters]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] State Department leaders worried that this left the department's communications infrastructure vulnerable to catastrophic disasters and emergencies, and thus in 1984 [[United States Congress|Congress]] authorized the construction of a backup communications facility, the Beltsville Communications Center, in Beltsville, Maryland, {{convert|14|mi}} north of the capital. The facility has since expanded to become a major communications network management center, serving as the primary hub of the Diplomatic Telecommunications Service.<ref name=hedges>{{cite magazine |last=Hedges |first=John S., III |title=At Beltsville, They Get the Message |magazine=[[State Magazine]] |date=May 1998 |issue=414 |pages=16–17 |url=http://2001-2009.state.gov/documents/organization/83431.pdf}}</ref><ref name=state1>{{cite book |title=U.S. Department of State Foreign Affairs Manual Volume 5 Handbook 2: Telecommunications Handbook |publisher=[[U.S. Department of State]] |date=June 6, 2012 |chapter=5-FAH 2 H-510: DTS Network |chapterurl=https://fam.state.gov/FAM/05FAH02/05FAH020510.html |accessdate=13 Dec 2015}}</ref> The facility covers {{convert|142000|sqft}} and, as of 1998, was staffed by 32 [[United States federal civil service|civil service]] and [[United States Foreign Service|foreign service]] employees and 56 contract support personnel.<ref name=hedges />
==Functions== According to the Department of State, the BIMC is charged with "eliminating the potential for disruption or loss of telecommunications between the Department and its mission abroad". The Beltsville center must continue to operate when the communications center at the department's headquarters cannot. The '''Alternate Communications Center''', which is housed within the complex, allows messages to be relayed without being routed through the department's primary communications center. In 1998, the center was reported to relay more than 143,000 official records and 90,000 data messages to diplomatic posts and foreign affairs agencies each day. An onsite fuel storage facility can sustain the BIMC for 38 days, while a {{convert|150000|USgal|l|adj=on|abbr=off}} water tank can sustain the center for at least eight days—the site consumes between {{convert|8000|and|10000|USgal|l|abbr=off}} of water each day to maintain a stable temperature and cool mainframe computers. The BIMC also houses the '''Foreign Affairs Data Processing Center''', which moved into a {{convert|99000|sqft}} addition to the complex in 1991.<ref name=hedges />
The [[United States Agency for International Development]] (USAID) has moved several programs into the BIMC. In 1995, the facility began serving as the central delivery point for USAID's [[information technology]] services. In 1997, USAID moved its Emergency Operations Center to the BIMC.<ref name=hedges />
===Special Collection Service=== {{Main|Special Collection Service}} The BIMC is located next door to the headquarters of the U.S. Special Collection Service, a joint [[Central Intelligence Agency]]–[[National Security Agency]] eavesdropping program.<ref name=fp12>{{cite magazine |last=Aid |first=Matthew |authorlink=Matthew Aid |title=The Spies Next Door: The Top 10 Beltway Intel Centers Hiding in Plain Sight |magazine=[[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]] |date=September 21, 2012 |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2012/09/21/the_spies_next_door |accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=today01>{{cite episode |credits=[[Ann Curry]] (anchor), John Pike (guest), [[Pete Williams (journalist)|Pete Williams]] (guest) and [[James Bamford]] (guest) |title=Congress to Hold Closed Hearings on Accused Spy Robert Hanssen Later This Week |series=Today |serieslink=Today (U.S. TV program) |network=[[NBC]] |airdate=February 27, 2001 |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2001/010227-spy.htm}}</ref> According to ''[[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]]'', satellite imagery from the 1990s shows fiber optic cable linking the SCS headquarters to the BIMC, which indicates that the BIMC services the communications needs of the SCS.<ref name=fp12 /> According to ''[[The Week]]'', when SCS personnel are deployed abroad, they often work ostensibly as members of the Diplomatic Telecommunications Service.<ref name=week>{{cite magazine |last=Brown |first=David W. |title=Inside the secret world of America's top eavesdropping spies |magazine=[[The Week]] |date=April 12, 2012 |url=http://theweek.com/article/index/226723/inside-the-secret-world-of-americas-super-sophisticated-eavesdropping-spies |accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove article|date=August 2016}} [[File:Biel-Leubringen-Bahn 2009.jpg|thumb|right|The central station of the line]] The '''Bienne–Evilard Funicular''' ([[German language|German]]:'''''Leubringenbahn'''''; [[French language|French]]:'''''Funiculaire Bienne–Evilard''''') is a [[funicular railway]] in the bilingual city of [[Biel/Bienne]] in the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[canton of Bern]]. The funicular links Biel/Bienne with [[Evilard|Leubringen/Evilard]] in the [[Jura mountains]] above the town.{{cite web | url = http://www.funimag.com/suisse/evilard01.htm | title = BM - Bienne - Evilard (Biel - Leubringen) | publisher = Funimag | accessdate = 2011-10-12}} The line is operated by the FUNIC company, who also operate the nearby [[Biel–Magglingen Funicular]]. == Operation == The line has the following parameters:''Réseau ferré suisse'', Secrétariat général CFF, Berne 1997, rééd. AS Verlag, {{ISBN|978-3-909111-74-9}} {| class=wikitable |- |Number of cars |2 |- |Number of stops |3 (at terminals and passing loop) |- |Maximum [[Grade (slope)|steepness]] |(?) |- |Configuration |[[Single track (rail)|Single track]] with [[passing loop]] |- |Track length |{{convert|933|m}} |- |[[Track gauge]] |{{convert|1000|mm}} |- |Rise |{{convert|242|m}} |- |Travel time |6 minutes |- |} == See also == * [[List of funicular railways]] * [[List of funiculars in Switzerland]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *{{commonscat-inline|Biel/Bienne–Leubringen/Evilard funicular}} *[http://www.funic.ch/ Official web site of the FUNIC company] (in German and French)

revision.text:
ImmuneHealth (former '''BioVallée''') is a flexible structure able to design, set-up, recruit, conduct epidemiology studies and provide immunomonitoring readouts.
This company has access to Human Biological Samples of various types (blood, urine, saliva, biopsies...), and supply generic (biobank retrospective approach) or custom ones on demand (prospective approach).
ImmuneHealth is able to provide QC methods with development from scratch, testing, qualification, validation, technical transfer, consulting and training activities through ELISA, ELISpot, Multiplex, rt(q)PCR, sequencing, pyrosequencing, FACS, ICS, microneutralization, binding assays, CAPS... ImmuneHealth's laboratories are ISO, GCLP compliant and GMP certified since 2013.
ImmuneHealth is a Centre Agréé de Recherche and consequently a non-lucrative entity bridging the gap between R&D fundamental and clinical research, and translates basic immunology into medicine. Our versatile structure is able to provide proof of concept for new products and to discover and validate immunobiomarker panels. ImmuneHealth is currently engages into several European and regional projects (FEDER, FP6, FP7) developing its own portfolio with a related network in the diagnostic and theranostic field.
To be counted among partners, GSK Vaccines, Biocygnus, Pevion, Genticel, Neovacs, Cardio3, MaSTherCell...
==See also== * [[Science Parks of Wallonia]] * [[Aéropole Science Park]] * [[BioLiège]]
==Sources== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080223142030/http://recherche-technologie.wallonie.be/fr/menu/par-themes/biotechnologies/universites-et-centres-de-recherche/biovallee-asbl.html?PROFIL= BioVallée] * [https://archive.is/20070502235529/http://clusterbois.clusters.wallonie.be/rechercheclinique/en/news/200706-biovallee.html BioVallée]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080211095749/http://www.biovallee.be/ BioVallée] * [http://www.ImmuneHealth.eu/ ImmuneHealth]

{{Infobox football biography | name = Charles Atsina | image = | caption = | fullname = Charles Atsina (Carlo) | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1989|3|24|df=y}}<ref name="dob">{{cite web | url=http://www.footballzz.com/jogador.php?id=186083&epoca_id=139 | title=Charles Atsina | publisher=www.footballzz.com | accessdate=1 August 2013}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Takoradi]], [[Ghana]] | height = 1.83 m | position = [[Forward (Association Football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[KS Kastrioti|Kastrioti]] | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 2009–2011 | clubs1 = [[Virtus Vecomp Verona]] | caps1 = | goals1 = | years2 = 2011–2012 | clubs2 = [[AD Alcorcon]] | caps2 = | goals2 = | years3 = 2013–2014 | clubs3 = Bochum II | caps3 = 26 | goals3 = 11 | years4 = 2014–2015 | clubs4 = [[Ennepetal]] | caps4 = 22 | goals4 =10 | years5 = 2017 | clubs5 = [[FK Panevėžys]] | caps5 = 15 | goals5 = 5 | years6 = 2017–2018 | clubs6 = [[KF Vllaznia Shkodër|Vllanzia]] | caps6 = 10 | goals6 = 2 | years7 = 2018– | clubs7 = [[KS Kastrioti|Kastrioti]] | caps7 = 0 | goals7 = 0 | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | medaltemplates = | club-update = | nationalteam-update = }}
'''Charles Buaku Atsina Junior''' is a [[Ghanaian]]-born [[Italy|Italian]] professional football player currently playing for [[KS Kastrioti|Kastrioti]] in the [[Albanian Superliga]]. Born on 24th March 1989, he grew up in Italy where he started his football academy in Verona. 2012 joined the Spanish liga2 [[AD Alcorcon]].<ref>https://www.ceroacero.es/equipa.php?id=16232&epoca_id=141</ref>
2013 discovered by the scout of [[Vfl Wolfsburg]] [[Frank Benatelli]] ex professional leggend player of Bochum and 2013 he joined the German side club Bochum.
In 2015, he joined Tus Ennepetal and become the only player to score 5goals in a game during the 1st round of the German kreispokal.<ref>https://www.derwesten.de/sport/lokalsport/ennepetal-gevelsberg-schwelm/widerstand-haelt-nur-eine-stunde-id9963722.html</ref><ref name="CA">{{cite web | url=http://www.ghanasoccernet.com/ghanaian-charles-atsina-makes-history-by-scoring-eight-goals-for-club-in-germany-tourney | title=Ghanaian Charles Atsina makes history by scoring EIGHT goals for club in Germany tourney | publisher=ghanasoccernet.com | accessdate=1 August 2013}}</ref>
On 28 July 2013, he became the first Ghanaian and Italian footballer to score eight goals in 60mins during a tournament of Rodemann cup in Bochum,Germany. His team beat [[DJK Adler Dahlhausen 1923 e.V.]] 13-1 in the [[Rodemann Cup]].<ref>https://ghanasoccernet.com/ghanaian-charles-atsina-makes-history-by-scoring-eight-goals-for-club-in-germany-tourney</ref><ref name="CA"/><ref name="llmnln">{{cite web | url=http://www.yardbarker.com/all_sports/articles/ghanaian_charles_atsina_makes_history_by_scoring_eight_goals_for_club_in_germany_tourney/14182508 | title=Ghanaian makes history | publisher=www.yardbarker.com | accessdate=1 August 2013}}</ref><ref>https://www.ceroacero.es/equipa.php?id=16232&epoca_id=141</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} http://www.sportcartagena.es/notas/2012/2/24/alcorcon-ficha-jugador-chino-proyeccion-futuro-108567.asp{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} http://futmadrid.com/historico/pref2/alcorconb/ad_alcorcon.htm http://www.presspeople.com/nota/chino-zhi-bin-li-prueba-alcorcon http://www.reviersport.de/281838---tus-ennepetal-atsina-trifft-trotz-sprachbarriere.html http://www.tus-ennepetal.de/

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
'''Democracy promotion''', which can also be referred to as '''democracy assistance''', '''democracy support''', or '''democracy building''', is a strand of foreign policy adopted by governments and international organizations that seek to support the spread of [[democracy]] as a [[political system]] around the world. Among the reasons for supporting democracy include the belief that countries with a democratic system of governance are less likely to go to war, are likely to be economically better off and socially more harmonious.<ref>see Peter Burnell, From Evaluating Democracy Assistance to Appraising Democracy Promotion, Political Studies Association, Political Studies 2008 VOL 56</ref>
Much experience has been gained in the last twenty years. After [[revolutions of 1989|the fall of the Iron Curtain in 1989]], there was a wave of democratic transitions in former [[communist]] states, particularly in Central and Eastern Europe. According to [[Freedom House]], the number of democracies has increased from 41 of 150 in 1974 existing states to 123 of 192 states in 2006<ref name="ODI">Lise Rakner, Alina Rocha Menocal and Verena Fritz (2008) [http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=1344&title=international-democracy-assistance-lessons-learned-can-donors-better-support-democratic-processes Assessing international democracy assistance: Key lessons and challenges] London: [[Overseas Development Institute]]</ref> (for Freedom House's most recent [http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=363&year=2007 data]). However, the pace of transition has slowed considerably since the beginning of the twenty-first century, which has encouraged some to ponder the question of whether democracy, far from advancing, may actually be under threat.<ref>Azar Gat, The Return of Authoritarian Great Powers, in Foreign Affairs, July–August 2007, [http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/62644/azar-gat/the-return-of-authoritarian-great-powers]</ref> In recent years, scholars have been pointing to a so-called [[democratic deficit]] in countries where democratic systems already exist, including Britain, the USA and the European Union.<ref>Saskia Sassen, Globalisation, the State and Democratic Deficit, Open Democracy, 18 July 2007, [http://www.opendemocracy.net/article/globalisation_liberal_state_democratic_deficit]; Patrice de Beer, France and Europe: the Democratic Deficit Exposed, Open Democracy, 4 June 2006, [http://www.opendemocracy.net/democracy-europe_constitution/democractic_deficit_3610.jsp]</ref>
The perceived challenge currently facing democracy around the world, both in countries where it is already at the core of the system of governance and in those where it is not, is encouraging academics and practitioners alike to re-evaluate what it means to promote, support or assist democracy in the post-[[Cold War]] situation.<ref>Christopher Hobson & Milja Kurki, Democracy and democracy-support: a new era, Open Democracy, 20 March 2009, [http://www.opendemocracy.net/article/idea/democracy-and-democracy-support-a-new-era]</ref>
== Definition == The precise definition of democracy promotion has been debated for more than twenty-five years. The multiplicity of terms used is a manifestation of the plurality of opinions and approaches by international actors, be they governments, [[NGO]]s or other third parties. For example, the term 'promotion' itself can be seen by some as too intrusive, or implying outside interference, whilst 'support' can be seen by some as more benign but, by others, as insufficiently assertive. These days the differences tend to divide into two main camps: those who see it as a political process on one hand and those who see it as a developmental process on the other (see [[international relations]] and [[development aid]] for context).<ref>Thomas Carothers, 'Democracy Assistance: Political vs. Developmental', in Journal of Democracy vol.20, no.1, January 2009</ref> {{Quote box |title = |quote = This basic division between the political and developmental approaches has existed inchoately in the field of democracy support for many years. It has come into sharper relief during this decade, as democracy-aid providers face a world increasingly populated by countries not conforming to clear or coherent political transitional paths. [...] Some adherents of the developmental approach criticize the political approach as too easily turning confrontational vis-à-vis “host” governments and producing unhelpful counterreactions. Some adherents of the political approach, meanwhile, fault the developmental approach for being too vague and unassertive in a world where many leaders have learned to play a reform game with the international community, absorbing significant amounts of external political aid while avoiding genuine democratization. |source = [[Thomas Carothers]], 'Democracy Assistance: Political vs. Developmental', in Journal of Democracy vol.20, no.1, January 2009 pp.5–6 |align = |width = |border = |fontsize = |bgcolor = |style = |title_bg = |title_fnt = |tstyle = |qalign = |qstyle = |quoted = true |salign = |sstyle = }} At least part of the problem lies in the absence of a consensus on what [[democracy]] constitutes. Indeed, the late Professor W.B. Gallie pointed to the impossibility of finding a firm solution to such a question, by including democracy in a list of '[[essentially contested concepts]]'.<ref>Gallie (1956a), passim. Kekes (1977, p.71)</ref> To date, the disagreement over definitions has seen some actors focus on supporting technical systems of democratic governance (elections, government structures and the like), while others take the bottom-up approach of promoting citizen participation and building strong civil and political society to prepare the ground on which systems of government can then be planted.
== Types == [[Democracy]] promotion has two main patterns that depend on the type of [[democratization]] a [[State (polity)|state]] is dealing with: external [[Peacekeeping|intervention]] and as a solution to [[civil war]], or supporting an internal push for reform. Democracy promotion advocates are divided on which pattern tends to be most successful for the resources that democracy promotion programs invest; they are similarly divided on which components and factors of the democratization process are most important to the success of [[democratic consolidation]].
=== Post-civil war democratization === Civil wars cause a number of problems for democratization. Laura Armey and Robert McNab found that the longer a civil war lasts, and the more casualties it produces, the more hostile the warring factions become to each other; this hostility in turn makes stabilization along terms of peaceful competition, required in a democratic [[Regime type|regime]], more difficult. Problematically for democracy promotion, the same study found that quick, decisive victories for one faction—even an ostensibly pro-democratic rebellion—similarly discourage peaceful, electoral competition for control of a government after the conflict is over.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Armey|first=Laura E.|last2=McNab|first2=Robert M.|date=2015-01-01|title=Democratization and Civil War|url=|journal=Applied Economics|volume=47|issue=18|doi=|issn=1466-4283|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Leonard Wantchekon has suggested that one of the most reliable forces of democratization is a stalemated civil war, in which the original motivation for the conflict becomes irrelevant as the costs mount; this impels the factions to turn to a combination of internal and external arbitrators to forge a power-sharing agreement: elections and outside, neutral institutions to guarantee that every faction participates in the new democracy fairly.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Leonard|first=Wantchekon|date=2004-02-01|title=The Paradox of Democracy: A Theoretical Investigation|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S0003055404000978|journal=American Political Science Review|volume=null|issue=01|pages=17–33|doi=10.1017/S0003055404000978|issn=1537-5943}}</ref>
==== External intervention ==== External interventions see different levels of democratization success depending on the type of intervener, type of intervention, and level of elite cooperation prior to the intervention. The level of neutrality and geopolitical disinterest the intervener possesses is important, as is the severity of the intervention's infringement on sovereignty. The differences can be highlighted with three examples: a neutral, mostly unobtrusive monitor missions like UN [[Election monitoring|election observers]] in Nicaragua in 1989; the [[Multilateralism|multilateral]] [[Implementation Force|NATO IFOR]] mission in Yugoslavia to enforce [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1031|UN Security Council Resolution 1031]] in 1995; and the [[Unilateralism|unilateral]], destabilizing intervention represented by the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|American invasion of Iraq]] in 2003. All three missions aimed on some level to promote democracy, with varying degrees of success. Michael Doyle and Nicholas Sambanis have found that the peacekeeping missions most successful at producing fledgling democracies have strong mandates backing them up, but tend not to revolve around military enforcement. Successful democratizing interventions consist of monitoring factions' adherence to their [[Settlement (litigation)|negotiated settlement]], while the most successful ones include extensive [[state-building]] (such as improving [[government efficiency]] and [[professionalism]], or classical [[Infrastructure|infrastructure assistance]]).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Doyle|first=Michael|last2=Sambanis|first2=Nicholas|date=2000-12-01|title=International peacebuilding: A theoretical and quantitative analysis|url=|journal=The American Political Science Review|volume=94|issue=4|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Problems with external intervention ==== Interventions that fail to expend resources on state-building can sometimes be counter-productive to democracy promotion because, as McBride, Milante, and Skaperdas have proposed, a negotiated settlement to a civil war is based on individual factions' faith in the [[State (polity)|state's]] unbiased distribution of the benefits of [[Failed state|stability]]; an external intervention shakes that faith by implying that such faith was misplaced to begin with.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McBride|first=Michael|last2=Milante|first2=Gary|last3=Skaperdas|first3=Stergios|date=2011-06-01|title=Peace and war with endogenous state capacity|url=|journal=The Journal of Conflict Resolution|volume=55|issue=3|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> An additional problem raised by Marina Ottaway is that interventions too often rush to implement formal democratic institutions, such as elections, without allowing time for competing elites to separate responsibly; because of the short timeframe, they either unite into a new [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] arrangement or rely on overly divisive party platforms, such as identity, which precludes “permanent fragmentation” of the [[elite]] within a cooperative regime framework.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Collapsed States: The Disintegration and Restoration of Legitimate Authority|last=Ottaway|first=Marina|publisher=L. Rienner Publishers|year=1995|isbn=1555875602|editor-last=Zartman|editor-first=I. William|location=Boulder, CO|pages=|chapter=Democratization in Collapsed States}}</ref> A final concern raised with external interventions, particularly unilateral or narrowly multilateral ones, is the perception or actualization of [[imperialism]] or [[neo-imperialism]] in the name of human rights or democracy by an interested party, which, she theorizes, spawns counter-productive [[Nationalism|nationalist]] backlash; however, even neutral monitors must be careful that their reports do not invite a unilateral intervention, as the Council of Freely-Elected Heads of Government's 1989 report on [[Panama]]nian [[Electoral fraud|election fraud]] did for the United States.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chand|first=Vikram|date=1997-01-01|title=Democratisation from the outside in: Ngo and international efforts to promote open elections|url=|journal=Third World Quarterly|doi=10.1080/01436599714867|issn=1360-2241|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Gradual reformism and the four-player game === Another school of thought on how democratization most successfully occurs involves an authoritarian regime transitioning to a democratic one as a result of gradual reforms over time. The basic mechanism for this is a four-player [[Game theory|game theoretical]] set-up in which moderate regime and opposition figures form a pro-democratic reform coalition to sideline their respective hardliners, whom they fear threaten the state's stability.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Issues in Democratic Consolidation: The New South American Democracies in Comparative Perspective|last=Mainwaring|first=Scott|publisher=University of Notre Dame Press|year=1992|isbn=0268012105|location=|pages=|chapter=The Games of Transition}}</ref> However, Alfred Stepan and Juan Linz raise a caveat to that picture: it requires both a highly [[institution]]alized regime and public sphere. The regime must not be [[Sultanism|sultanistic]] (based entirely around one central ruler's desires) in order that different members retain some degree of autonomy and have different interests; meanwhile, in the [[public sphere]], there must be a strong [[civil society]] that can both maintain pressure on the authoritarian regime while also providing support for the reform pact and the moderates who formulated it.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TqRn1lAypsgC|title=Problems of Democratic Transition and Consolidation: Southern Europe, South America, and Post-Communist Europe|last=Linz|first=Juan J.|last2=Stepan|first2=Alfred|date=1996-08-08|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=9780801851582|language=en}}</ref> As Ray Salvatore Jennings explains, over the past half century, the success of [[democratic transitions]] has depended substantially on the ability of [[civil society organizations]] (CSOs) to disseminate dissident information to counter authoritarian regimes' narratives, as well as their mobilizing high voter turnout and monitoring the first elections to prevent interference by hardliner members of the regime.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jennings|first=Ray Salvatore|date=2012-01-01|title=Democratic breakthroughs: the ingredients of successful revolts|url=|journal=Peaceworks|publisher=US Institute for Peace|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Further, many scholars partial to the gradual reformism perspective on democratization agree with Francis Fukuyama, who asserts that the role of CSOs in directing the part of individuals' lives not under the [[Liberal democracy|liberal democratic]] state's control makes CSOs critical to sustaining the social capital and self-advocacy important for liberal democracy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fukuyama|first=Francis|date=2001-01-01|title=Social capital, civil society and development|url=|journal=Third World Quarterly|volume=22|issue=1|doi=10.1080/713701144 |pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Conflict over support for internal reform ==== Even beyond the question of what and whether external intervention is an effective democracy support strategy, a number of issues continue to divide the proponents of a democracy support-based international policy. [[Carles Boix]] and Susan Stokes advocate economic development aid, contending that the more advanced an economy, the less willing factions will be to break the peace; others, however, contend that this strategy is only useful at defending democratic consolidation, and not at encouraging democratization of regimes where one faction already dominates.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Boix|first1=Carles|authorlink1=Carles Boix|last2=Stokes|first2=Susan Carol|date=2003-01-01|title=Endogenous Democratization|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/journals/world_politics/v055/55.4boix.html|journal=World Politics|volume=55|issue=4|pages=517–549|doi=10.1353/wp.2003.0019|issn=1086-3338}}</ref> Still others fall in Freytag and Heckelman's camp, advocating the long-game, positing that although [[United States Agency for International Development|USAID]] programs have so far had little net effect on democratization, they have demonstrably improved basic democratic features, including civil society and the electoral process, in countries receiving aid.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Freytag|first=Andreas|date=2012-12-01|title=Has Assistance from USAID been Successful for Democratization? Evidence from the Transition Economies of Eastern Europe and Eurasia|url=|journal=Journal of Institutional and Theoretical Economics JITE|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
It is also worth noting that not all CSOs will be helpful in promoting democracy—if the organization is too large to inspire its members, or its constituents' identity is too narrowly defined, the organization will fail to support four-player democratic transition pacts, and may even encourage divisiveness and civil war.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Orjuela|first=Camilla|date=2005-07-01|title=Civil Society in Civil War: The Case of Sri Lanka.|url=|journal=Civil Wars|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> There is also some concern that the international community may be propping up NGOs to the point that they themselves become an unrepresentative elite.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bermeo|first=Nancy|date=2003-04-01|title=What the democratization literature says--or doesn't say--about postwar democratization|url=|journal=Global Governance|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[American democracy promotion in the Middle East and North Africa]]
==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last1=Bollen |first1=Kenneth |authorlink1=Kenneth Bollen |last2=Paxton |first2=Pamela |last3=Morishima |first3=Rumi |date=June 2005 |title=Assessing international evaluations: An example from USAID’s Democracy and Governance Programs |journal=American Journal of Evaluation |volume=26 |number=2 |pages=189–203 |ref=harv |url=http://www.irss.unc.edu/odum/content/pdf/Bollen_Paxton_Morishima2005AJE.pdf |format=pdf |doi=10.1177/1098214005275640 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Evaluation performed on behalf of the [[Social Science Research Council]] (SSRC), at the request of and with funding from the Strategic and Operational Research Agenda (SORA) of [[USAID]] (Office of Democracy and Governance in the Bureau for Democracy, Conflict, and Humanitarian Assistance), according to the {{harvtxt|National Research Council|2008|p=28}} * [[Thomas Carothers]], ''Critical Mission: Essays on Democracy Promotion'', Washington, DC: Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, 2004, {{ISBN|978-0-87003-209-7}} * Nicolas Guilhot, ''The Democracy Makers: Human Rights and International Order'', New York: Columbia University Press, 2005, {{ISBN|978-0-231-13124-7}} * {{cite book |first=Committee on Evaluation of USAID Democracy Assistance Programs |last=National Research Council |authorlink=United_States_National_Research_Council |title=Improving democracy assistance: Building knowledge through evaluations and research|editor-first=Jack A|editor-last=Goldstone|editor-link=Jack A. Goldstone|pages=xvi+336|year=2008|isbn=978-0-309-11736-4 |url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog/12164.html|ref=harv }}[http://download.nap.edu/cart/download.cgi?&record_id=12164&free=1 Free PDF-formatted complete report] * {{cite book|title=Freedom from oppression: Government communication on Swedish democracy support |date=26 September 2008|first=Ministry for Foreign Affairs|last=Sweden|url=http://www.sweden.gov.se/download/5013cca7.pdf?major=1&minor=116271&cn=attachmentPublDuplicator_0_attachment |format=pdf|isbn=978-91-7496-395-3 |publisher=Department for Development Policy and the Press and Communication Department, Ministry for Foreign Affairs |ref=harv}} * {{cite book|title=Change for freedom: Policy for democratic development and human rights in Swedish development cooperation, 2010-2014|date=21 January 2010|first=Ministry for Foreign Affairs|last=Sweden|url=http://www.sweden.gov.se/download/14dceded.pdf?major=1&minor=143233&cn=attachmentPublDuplicator_0_attachment|format=pdf|isbn=978-91-7496-422-6|publisher=Department for Development Policy and the Press and Communication Department, Ministry for Foreign Affairs|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Thiel|first=Rainer|chapter= U.S. democracy assistance in the Polish liberalization process 1980-1989 (Chapter 6)|title=Nested games of external democracy promotion: The United States and the Polish liberalization 1980-1989|year=2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AbmPRK8hK3wC&q=Kahn#v=snippet&q=Kahn&f=false|pages=179–235, especially 204 and 231|isbn=978-3-531-17769-4|publisher=VS Verlag|ref=harv}}

{{Politics of the European Union}} The '''Directorate-General for Education, Youth, Sport and Culture ''' (former Directorate-General for Education and Culture) ("DG EAC") is a [[Directorate-General]] of the [[European Commission]].
The Education, Youth, Sport and Culture Directorate-General is responsible of policies in the field of education, youth, culture, languages and sport.
==Structure==
DG EAC is divided into 5 "directorates":
* Directorate A : Policy Strategy and Evaluation * Directorate B : Youth, Education and [[Erasmus+]] * Directorate C : Innovation, International Cooperation and Sport * Directorate D : Culture and Creativity * Directorate R : Performance Management, Supervision and Resources
It oversees the European Union's [[Education, Audiovisual and Culture Executive Agency]] (EACEA), which handles most operational programmes on DG EAC's behalf.
==See also== * [[European Commissioner for Education, Culture, Multilingualism and Youth]] * [[Education in the European Union]] * [[European Higher Education Area]] * [[Bologna process]] * [[Erasmus programme]] * [[Cultural policies of the European Union]] * [[European Capital of Culture]] * [[Culture of Europe]] * [[Town twinning]]
== External links == * [http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/education_culture/index_en.html Directorate-General for Education and Culture] * [http://www.ehea.info The Official European Higher Education Area website 2010-2020]
{{-}} {{Eu-directorates-general}}
[[Category:Directorates-General in the European Commission|Education and Culture]]
{{EU-stub}}

[[File:EUMETNET Members map.svg|thumb|right|250px|EUMETNET members in blue and cooperating organisations in green.]] '''EUMETNET''' is a network of 31 European National Meteorological Services based in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]]. It exists to provide a framework to organise co-operative programmes between the members in fields of [[meteorology]], data processing and forecasting products.
==Members== Meteorological services of the following 31 countries are members of EUMETNET: Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Montenegro, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Macedonia and the United Kingdom.
Cooperating non-member states: Bulgaria, Israel, Lithuania, Moldova and Romania.
== See also == * [[European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites|EUMETSAT]] * [[European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts|ECMWF]] * [[Meteoalarm]]
==External links== * [http://www.eumetnet.eu/ Official website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Eumetnet}} [[Category:Governmental meteorological agencies in Europe]] [[Category:Organisations based in Brussels]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Lietuvos Radijo Mėgėjų Draugija
Lithuanian Amateur Radio Society |image = LRMD_logo.png |image_border = |size = 93px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = LRMD |motto = |formation = October 2, 1938 |extinction = |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = |purpose = Advocacy, Education |headquarters = |location = [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]] |region_served = [[Lithuania]] |membership = |language = [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] |leader_title = Chairman |leader_name = Simonas Kareiva LY2EN [http://www.lrmd.lt/valdyba_en.htm Board of LRMD, elected at a general meeting in Vilnius, on March 12, 2016] |main_organ = |affiliations = [[International Amateur Radio Union]] |num_staff = |budget = |website = http://www.lrmd.lt/ |remarks = }} The '''Lietuvos Radijo Mėgėjų Draugija''' ('''LRMD''') (in [[English language|English]], '''Lithuanian Amateur Radio Society''') is a national [[non-profit organization]] for [[amateur radio]] enthusiasts in [[Lithuania]]. LRMD represents the interests of Lithuanian amateur radio operators before Lithuanian, European, and international telecommunications regulatory authorities.Lietuvos Radijo Mėgėjų Draugija (2017). [http://www.lrmd.lt/ Lietuvos Radijo Mėgėjų Draugija] official web site. Retrieved Jan. 28, 2017. LRMD is the national member society representing Lithuania in the [[International Amateur Radio Union]].International Amateur Radio Union (2008). [http://www.iaru.org/iaru-soc.html "Member Societies"]. Retrieved Aug. 1, 2008. == History == According to the LRMD web site, the society was founded in 1938 and was re-activated in 1988. In 1939, it was recognized as the national member for Lithuania by the IARU.[http://www.lrmd.lt/index_en.htm Brief history of LRMD][http://foto.qrz.lt/LY2EN/ARRL_LRMD_1939/ Calendar of IARU, Dec 1939] Most of the modern-time LRMD activity is documented in the LY-[[QTC (magazine)|QTC]] magazine, which was published from 1989 till 2011.[http://www.lrmd.lt/qtc.htm LY-QTC archive (Lithuanian)] In 2013, LRMD supported the [[LituanicaSAT-1]] project, the first Lithuanian nanosatellite in [[low Earth orbit]].[https://amsat-uk.org/2013/04/12/lituanicasat-1/ LituanicaSAT-1 with amateur radio FM transponder to deploy from ISS] LRMD is a participant in the "Youngsters on the air" initiative by [[International Amateur Radio Union|IARU]] since 2013.[http://www.ham-yota.com/team-photos/?albumid=1520&pageid=2] Together with [[Lietuvos Skautija]], the primary national [[Scouting]] organization of Lithuania, LRMD is hosting annual [[Jamboree on the Air]] events.[http://www.skautai.lt/index/article/id/2528] == Member services == Key membership benefits of LRMD include the sponsorship of [[amateur radio operating award]]s and radio [[contesting|contests]], and a [[QSL card|QSL]] bureau for those members who regularly communicate with [[amateur radio operator]]s in other countries.[http://www.lrmd.lt/bureau LRMD QSL bureau] LRMD provides web page, photo gallery hosting and email services for its members upon request.[http://foto.qrz.lt/] The society is responsible for the annual amateur radio operator festival in Lithuania, the LRMD Hamfest.[http://www.lrmd.lt/hamfest/english.htm] According to the LRMD web site, the society has 375 active members.[http://www.lrmd.lt/mokejimai LRMD membership fees (2017)] Retrieved Jan. 28, 2017. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.lrmd.lt/index_en.htm Official LRMD web page (English)] * [https://www.facebook.com/lrmd.lt LRMD news and updates, Facebook] * [http://foto.qrz.lt/ LRMD photo gallery] {{DEFAULTSORT:Lietuvos Radijo Megeju Draugija}} [[Category:International Amateur Radio Union member societies|Lithuania]] [[Category:Non-profit organisations based in Lithuania]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1938]] [[Category:1938 establishments in Lithuania]] [[Category:Radio in Lithuania]] [[Category:Organisations based in Vilnius]] {{Amateur-radio-start}} {{Lithuania-stub}}
